instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: This <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> has <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and G3H, SYS ONEWIRE = 3.4 and BC-ACOK also present. I get how the one wire works for Pro but for air seems to work different? I remember that I saw a vid from Lewis about it but i cant find it. If you can point me in the right direction I can check it first myself. Tips also welcome as customer needs to leave Thailand tomorrow and its 12AM so I have only one night to get it fixed :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: Does the machine power on? What is PPBUS voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: No there is no fan and no LED. PPBUS 8.22v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: PPBUS 8.2V means SMC is not running. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> present? Corrosion around SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: There was corrosion around SMC indeed, I have tried to reflow but that didnt work should i try to reball it instead?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: No, you should find out if <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is high or low.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> is high then it is probably crap under it or it is dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: I have to give up on it as the customer is leaving back home tonight :( on to the next one thanks for the help learned a lot again! One question, can you buy SMC chip from china pre-balled and use those or do they need to be from the board itself? I bought a lot of IC from China (non SMC) and so far they have always worked fine, most where power IC though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: SMC chip has firmware and needs to come from an identical donor board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
threads.message: OK now I have 1 more month to fix this issue ;). I do have a donor board but I do not have the reballing stencil do you happen know where i can get those, maybe somewhere of Ebay?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no led
